publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-601# Bill Aitken: Bus Corridors in Glasgow—That the Parliament notes the concerns of businesses in Glasgow about the effects of bus corridors on the main arterial routes in and out of the city on local businesses, and believes that the local authority should give the fullest possible consideration to the views of small businesses prior to the imposition of these schemes, in view of the potential adverse consequences on employment.
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Mr Keith Harding*, Ms Sandra White*

S1M-601# Bill Aitken: Bus Corridors in Glasgow—That the Parliament notes the concerns of businesses in Glasgow about the effects of bus corridors on the main arterial routes in and out of the city on local businesses, and believes that the local authority should give the fullest possible consideration to the views of small businesses prior to the imposition of these schemes, in view of the potential adverse consequences on employment. Supported by: Mr Keith Harding, Ms Sandra White
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Dorothy-Grace Elder*
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Robert Brown*
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Tommy Sheridan*

S1M-601# Bill Aitken: Bus Corridors in Glasgow—That the Parliament notes the concerns of businesses in Glasgow about the effects of bus corridors on the main arterial routes in and out of the city on local businesses, and believes that the local authority should give the fullest possible consideration to the views of small businesses prior to the imposition of these schemes, in view of the potential adverse consequences on employment. Supported by: Mr Keith Harding, Ms Sandra White, Dorothy-Grace Elder, Robert Brown, Tommy Sheridan
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) David Mundell*
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Mr David Davidson*

S1M-601# Bill Aitken: Bus Corridors in Glasgow—That the Parliament notes the concerns of businesses in Glasgow about the effects of bus corridors on the main arterial routes in and out of the city on local businesses, and believes that the local authority should give the fullest possible consideration to the views of small businesses prior to the imposition of these schemes, in view of the potential adverse consequences on employment. Supported by: Mr Keith Harding, Ms Sandra White, Dorothy-Grace Elder, Robert Brown, Tommy Sheridan, David Mundell, Mr David Davidson
S1M-601# Bus Corridors in Glasgow (lodged on 28 February 2000) Mr Kenny MacAskill*
